Comment: Every comment in here so far is asinine.   Yes. Presidential elections at the top of of the ticket drive voter turnout.   In general, during presidential elections, voter turnout is around 66%.   In general, during midterm elections, when Senate, House and state and local elections are on the ballot only, voter turnout is around 40%  That's a difference of tens of millions of people turning out to vote.   Virtually all voters have an opinion of presidential candidates. That is less true in contests for Senate, House, Governor. It's exponentially more true for other state, county and city elections.   99% of people can name their president.  70% of people can name one of their Senators 60% of people can name their governor 50% of people can name their House Representative   The number of people who can name their state House member or city council member, is very small.    Imagine a city who holds its city council election on a random Tuesday in June. No other elections are on the ballot.   Voter participation will be 10% or less.   Imagine that same city holding it city council election on the same as the election for President of the United States.   There will be 7x more people turning out (because of the POTUS election) but this also means that 7x times more people will vote for city council (or might vote for city council)  In this regard - the Presidential election will inevitably impact the results of the local city council election - given that 7x as many people are participating- but also - because many of those voters now participating are "low information" voters - people who only turnout to vote in presidential election cycles.   For more on this look up "under vote" and "split ticket voting"  Source: I worked in campaigns and elections professionally for over a decade, with speclization in voter turnout metrics and tactics.
